awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the contribution of alpine glacier meltwater to mountain-block recharge using microbiological markers and environmental isotopes
awd_abstract_narration:
Glaciers occur in mountains across the globe. Water from melting glaciers is important to humans and other organisms. Some of this water goes directly to streams while some will flow deep into the ground and refill groundwater. It is not known how much melt-water goes directly to streams versus to groundwater. This project uses water chemistry and biological data to determine where the water goes when a glacier melts. The project examines water from glaciers on Mt. Hood in Oregon and from glaciers in Glacier National Park in Montana. This project is training graduate students and multiple undergraduate students. The results are presented at scientific meetings and to water managers. The results are also available to the public via pamphlets and news articles.   

More than ninety percent of the Earth's alpine glaciers are in retreat and many of these glaciers will melt completely within this century. Very little research has been conducted on the impacts of alpine glacial meltwater to recharge and flow within the mountain block. This project seeks to identify the contribution of alpine glacial meltwater to mountain recharge relative to seasonal snow and rain using chemical and biological approaches. This research tests the following hypotheses: 1) The glacial environment selects for unique biota resulting in deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) fingerprints in alpine glacial meltwater that are distinct from seasonal snow and rain;  2) Alpine glacial meltwater is a significant source of mountain recharge and sustains perennial flow to local and regional-scale springs located down-gradient of alpine glaciers. This research assesses the novel application of DNA as a tracer for mountain recharge and increases the ability to detect recharge from alpine glaciers located in different geologic and geographic settings.  This study trains graduate students and multiple undergraduate researchers and engages with water managers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
More than 90 percent of the Earth’s alpine glaciers are in retreat and many of these glaciers will vanish within this century. Glacial meltwater is an important component of the alpine hydrologic cycle. Some of this meltwater becomes surface runoff and directly supports streamflow generation in alpine watersheds. Unfortunately, our understanding on how much of this meltwater infiltrates the sediment and eventually becomes groundwater recharge is limited. Recharge is the process through which aquifers are replenished. Much of the previous research on alpine meltwater processes has focused on the impacts to surface and shallow subsurface runoff processes. Very little research has been conducted on the impacts of alpine glacial meltwater to recharge and flow within the mountain block, processes which are critical to alpine ecosystems. Quantifying the subsurface partitioning of meltwater remains a challenging endeavor. In particular, identifying the contribution of alpine glacial meltwater to mountain recharge relative to seasonal snow and rain is not trivial since many of the traditional techniques used to infer these processes provide non-unique results. This research is guided by the following overarching hypotheses: 1) The glacial environment selects for unique biota resulting in DNA fingerprints in alpine glacial meltwater that are distinct from seasonal snow and rain.  2) Alpine glacial meltwater is a significant source of mountain recharge and sustains perennial flow to local- to regional-scale springs located downgradient of alpine glaciers.

The 2nd hypothesis was broken into two parts: 1) to determine how much glacial meltwater is discharged from alpine springs and in doing so, provide estimates on the importance of glacial meltwater to alpine aquifers and 2) to quantify the spatial importance of the isotopic fingerprint of glacial meltwater across spatial scales in Mount Hood and Glacier National Park. By combining stable isotopes of water, oxygen-18 (18O) and deuterium (2H), with microbiological metrics, we found that alpine glacier meltwater is a critical source of water for many springs and that alpine springs primarily supported by glacial meltwater contain microbial taxa that are unique from springs primarily supported by seasonal recharge from snow and rain. This isotopic mixing model shows that glacial meltwater is important across spatial scales, especially in Mount Hood. In Mount Hood, low-elevation springs maintained an isotopic fingerprint similar to alpine glaciers located several thousand feet higher than the spring emergence.

To address the 2nd part of the hypothesis, we used strontium isotopes (87Sr/86Sr) to identify the rock units that host groundwater flowpaths in both study sites and then we used a combination of tritium (3H), chlorine-36 (36Cl/Cl), and carbon isotopes (13C and 14C) to investigate the processes that affect the preservation of the isotopic fingerprint of glacial meltwater in the mountain aquifer system spanning from high elevations to low elevations. Strontium isotopic analyses show that hydrostratigraphy (the hydraulic properties of different rock layers affect flow properties of the entire whole) affects groundwater circulation (the depth to which groundwater flows in the subsurface) and flowpath connectivity across spatial scales in Glacier National Park (GNP). The geology of Glacier National Park is very different than Mount Hood (MH); GNP is comprised of uplifted sedimentary rock layers whereas MH is a stratovolcano. Rock layers with higher conductivities are located at higher elevations in GNP and these units are underlain by low-permeability rock units. This stratigraphy essentially forces all the groundwater flow above the low-permeability units. However, the rock layers also dip to the south and this has a tremendous effect on groundwater flow routing and higher potential for spring emergences on south-facing slopes. In MH, the data provide evidence for deep groundwater circulation and stronger connectivity of groundwater flowpaths across spatial scales. We proposed a subsidiary hypothesis that north-facing slopes should preserve ice longer than south-facing slopes and should therefore, have more springs than south-facing slopes. Again, hydrostratigraphy made it difficult to assess this hypothesis in GNP. However, the data support the subsidiary hypothesis in MH; there are more springs on north-facing slopes and more springs that are supported by recharge from glacial meltwater. Tritium proved to be challenging in this environment while chlorine-36 shows some utility in identifying components of recharge during the nuclear weapons testing era (1950s and 1960s). We assume that this bomb-pulse signal from the 1950s and 1960s was likely preserved in the ice and has melted from the glacial ice. Carbon isotopes show the most utility in tracing recharge from the glacier. The carbon-14 (14C) activity is lower than expected. There are numerous explanations for this observation, but preliminary models suggest it is due to the presence of old ice in the glacier. Additional testing is needed for this finding. For the 2nd part of the hypothesis, we found evidence that recharge from glacial meltwater is important across spatial scales; however, geological complexity may mask the effects of aspect on ice preservation in mountain aquifers.
